body: LGTM
LGTM
utcnow seems reasonable. But I would like to see a couple of tests as it would help making Airflow TZ aware in the future.
@bolkedebruin do you have any suggestions on what kind of test cases you would like? Particularly is there any part of the codebase I should focus on while testing?

> I'm ok with waiting for REST API if it's coming up soon, otherwise I think it may be more beneficial to have this merged (once I clean it up =P ).

I think it's worth getting this PR done. The REST API is likely a long ways away.

Ok I am doing some integration tests now, but running into problems right away unfortunately. I use a clean install, LocalExecutor to test. No "num-runs". DAGS start out paused.

When I turn one of the dags 'on' it does not get scheduled. Only when I restart the scheduler some tasks get picked up but it does not continue. I need to restart the scheduler every time to make it pick up more tasks. I assume you dont want us to be dependent on "num-runs" as we are just starting to be able to move away from it?

Basically it seems that new dag_runs are not getting scheduled. Is it missing a call?

In addition it seems to take quite a long time before tasks go from queued -> running. I still need to look a the "scheduled", "queued" -> "running" path.
`num_runs` was left in to facilitate testing, but it's not a required feature. If you set it to `-1`, the number of runs should not matter.
The time to go from `queued -> running` should not be long. I'll take a look into it as well.

It seems that it needs another iteration of the scheduler before it goes from queued -> "running" (running between quotes as I would consider this a different state than running as in the task is executing)

@bolkedebruin I noticed that subdag's TIs are created independently rather than via DagRun (there are currently no dagrun being created for subdags). Was wondering if this is intentional? imho it would make sense to create dagruns for subdags as well if we want to support mark success / clear a subdag via dagrun.
@jgao54 that is indeed so, but old style. I have a PR outstanding that does add dag runs to backfills (that is how subdags run) but it needs reviewing/testing
@bolkedebruin ah I see it! In that case I'll hold off this PR until yours is merged. I will need to make a bit of changes accordingly, but it will be cleaner.
If you can please review the other pr and +1 it. Thanks!
LGTM as well

+1 From the comment on the https://github.com/flask-admin/flask-admin/issues/1226, it doesn't sound like it will be fixed. Given that SQLite is here to stay for the foreseeable future and that more than 10 people have run into this, I think this is needed.

I've created the jira ticket and added tests.  I didn't see any assertions on the existing test suite:  https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/tests/operators/hive_operator.py#L40-L69

so I went ahead and took a mockist approach. Will resolve conflicts in my next update.

For the `BashOperator`, only the subprocess needs to be run as the specified user, not the entire airflow command. If the specified user doesn't have permissions to `airflow.cfg`, we should be set.
@jlowin Apologies - I only just saw this. Thank you for the hints. I have made the requested changes and the unit tests now pass.

Looks like the Qubole operator might need this, it was added in this PR: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/808/ .

At the moment we install the pip dependencies of all of the airflow operators, and we should be consistent in this. I filed this ticket: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-299 a while ago to separate hooks/operators from the airflow core, after which we should definitely do a sweeping cleanup of the dependencies. If you agree please close this PR.

👍 
![img](http://img07.deviantart.net/4401/i/2009/321/7/8/defend_yourself___kill_zombies_by_vaginasaurus_rex.png)

Conflicts merged and the CI failure looks due to `tox` failing to archive:
`The command "tox -e $TOX_ENV" exited with 1.`

Should be good to go.

OK, I might be too early in the plugin dependency cleaning process. But still, I [can't find any _direct_ import of Babel itself](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=babel) in Airflow's code base.

There's [no direct reference in Qubole operators](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/24d41b8909840451c1ef7d70c1c7671e6d87528c/airflow/contrib/operators/qubole_operator.py#L14-L18) either. Nor there is any reference to [Babel in Qubole's SDK](https://github.com/qubole/qds-sdk-py/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=babel).

So even if there's a hidden dependency somewhere, it's already taken into account by sub-packages: all [unit-tests are passing](https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-airflow/builds/145016866).

I'm annoyed by this restrictive dependency. There's no point of being too conservative in this case. We can safely get rid of Babel requirement.

If you still do not want to remove it, we can compromise by either:
- Move Babel requirement from the general section to the [`qds` section](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/9f49f12853d83dd051f0f1ed58b5df20bfcfe087/setup.py#L156), along the requirement on `qds-sdk`.
- Remove the Babel hard-limit on the 1.x series as such: `babel>=1.3` [instead of `babel>=1.3, <2.0`](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/9f49f12853d83dd051f0f1ed58b5df20bfcfe087/setup.py#L180).
Gotcha, thanks for investigating. LGTM

Actually looks like that commit I pointed to was just had a messed up git history (d0c32c90da1407ac55d7c9c2ac807edb6325d77a)

It was actually added here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/814
But there isn't much context.
cc @mistercrunch
Yeah, neither `babel` was added by me, nor `qds-sdk` needs babel at all.
Thanks @aoen for the quick merge! :)
@yiqingj please, follow the 50/72 commit message rules. Thanks.
@bolkedebruin, please take a look! Thanks :)
@impangt, please follow the 50/72 rule for the commit messages. Also, please, squash your commits into single one. Thanks.
@jgao54 @aoen adjusted how it works now. max_dag_run is respected now.
Thanks @bolkedebruin

@jgao54 good point. Further considering the max amount of dag runs in backfills creates a bit of an issue. As the BackfillJob waits on all runs to finish before it exits should I then wait for active_dag_runs < max_dag_runs which can be arbitrarily long?

BackfillJobs should indeed be scheduled, but although the change to the backfilljob logic is relatively small, all tests need to be updated. So that will take a bit longer and is outside the scope of this PR

@bolkedebruin yeah, agree that without using the scheduler, starvation is theoretically possible with backfills. 

I personally think that is an okay temporary sacrifice in order to respect max_active_run, since in _most_ cases a dag only has a single dagrun running, if at all (and the default config for max_active_run is 16).

Is anything using AirflowConfigException? Could this change break imports?
@bolkedebruin - checking up since it's been a while

I really appreciate the unrelated refactors, but it's confusing to have them in this PR/commits. I'd rather this feature as one PR, and another PR for a bundle of refactors.

Another nit is that once review is started it's usually good to add new commits instead of amending existing one. It makes it easier to understand the workflow and allow reviewers to insulate how comments have been addressed.

Apart from that the feature look good to me. We probably want to cherry pick into our production first and let it run for a little while before merging into master.
Moved pylint fixes to https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1690

https://landscape.io/github/zodiac/incubator-airflow/163/messages/error

Fair question. The configuration object itself does, especially when validating, and it looks like a few authentication modules do as well: github enterprise; ldap; the general authentication load in **init**.py. Not much, but a few places.

I doubt imports would break because there is still an `AirflowConfigException` in airflow.configuration, it just isn't created there anymore.
Also, I have absolutely no idea why this is causing only the Py2.7 sqlite travis build to fail. I thought it was random, but it fails every time.
Seems like most people prefer https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1685 - closing

The failures are unrelated.

What is this? Are you assuming that the DAGs dir is going to be a git repo?

> Are you assuming that the DAGs dir is going to be a git repo?

Yes, as stated in the first entry in "changes".
@r39132 does this overlap with any existing CLI functionality? Thought I recall being able to set variables via CLI already (can't find it now though, but CLI is getting pretty complex).
@criccomini currently the CLI is capable of manually setting and getting a variable. This adds functionality to import a file to set multiple at once, and also export values to a file.

Ah, got it. Nice!

Random thought: a similar feature for connections would be interesting (though would require passwords to be in the file). There was some discussion on the mailing list about this.
Is that a valid assumption? Thus far, I think Airflow has worked if the `dags` directory doesn't have a .git dir in it (or some parent).
I see this, though: `Opt-in via config file`. So this is the escape hatch to make it backwards compatible?

> I see this, though: Opt-in via config file. So this is the escape hatch to make it backwards compatible?

Yeah, the idea I'm working towards is for the user to be able to choose their method of version control via the config file, with the default being no version control (ie same behaviour as current master). Sorry if this was not clear.

I'm trying to isolate the git-specific logic to 2-3 functions, as in https://github.com/zodiac/incubator-airflow/blob/3e3715d5a15d09351e1944bdb56b5fe91bec16cf/airflow/version_control/__init__.py#L11-L12, so a new version control system (eg mercurial) can be implemented by writing those 2-3 functions.

It is not completely backwards-compatible, though, because I need to add a column to task_instance.

> It is not completely backwards-compatible, though, because I need to add a column to task_instance.

Should be fine, since we have `airflow upgradedb`

@criccomini the true value of this functionality is that we can now set up variables using automation! With this CLI subcommand for the existing variables command, we can easily set up a new airflow services, exporting and importing variables. I agree the connection export/import would be the next useful piece to add.
